title: Overview
text: two variables saved package work . template-statement pair describes weight apple. Let’s declare can see inside: idea behind rosettaR one may want model knowledge contained sentence multiple ways. template-statement pair constitutes core piece information (sometimes called “semantic anchor”) can transformed multiple representations. can turn data frame: ’s pretty straightforward usage, can get complicated . can transform statement CSV, slots become column headers values go columns: ’re still pretty simple territory , let’s get little complex. original idea behind Rosetta Statements make easier create knowledge graphs RDF. example RDF graph describes weight apple: Describing exactly TTL beyond scope vignette, reading likely idea RDF/OWL/etc. let’s feed string workflow see happens:
code: print(apple_template) #> [1] "{{ object }} has a {{ quality }} of {{ value }} {{ unit }}" print(apple_statement) #> [1] "Apple X has a weight of 241.68 grams" knitr::kable(rosetta_format(apple_statement, apple_template)) rosetta_format(apple_statement, apple_template, "Object,Quality,Value,Unit\n{{ object }},{{ quality }},{{ value }},{{ unit }}") #> [1] "Object,Quality,Value,Unit\nApple X,weight,241.68,grams" apple_rdf <- '@prefix ex:    <http://example.org/instance/> . @prefix ncit:  <http://ncicb.nci.nih.gov/xml/owl/EVS/Thesaurus.owl#> . @prefix pato:  <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/PATO_> . @prefix iao:   <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_> . @prefix obi:   <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_> . @prefix ro:    <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/RO_> . @prefix uo:    <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/UO_> . @prefix rdf:   <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> . @prefix rdfs:  <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> . @prefix xsd:   <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#> .  ############################################################ ## OBJECT: the particular apple ############################################################  ex:apple     rdf:type ncit:apple ;     rdfs:label "{{ object }}" ;     ro:has_quality ex:apple{{ quality }} .  ############################################################ ## QUALITY: weight of the apple ############################################################  ex:apple{{ quality }}     rdf:type pato:{{ quality }} ;                 # PATO:weight     iao:is_about ex:apple ;     iao:is_quality_measured_as ex:apple{{ quality }}Datum .  ############################################################ ## MEASUREMENT DATUM ############################################################  ex:apple{{ quality }}Datum     rdf:type iao:0000109 ;                  # IAO:scalar measurement datum     obi:has_value_specification ex:apple{{ quality }}ValueSpec .  ############################################################ ## VALUE SPECIFICATION ############################################################  ex:apple{{ quality }}ValueSpec     rdf:type obi:0001938 ;                  # OBI:scalar value specification     iao:has_measurement_value "{{ value }}"^^xsd:double ;     iao:has_measurement_unit_label uo:0000021 .  ############################################################ ## UNIT ############################################################  uo:0000021     rdf:type uo:{{ unit }} .' cat(rosetta_format(apple_statement, apple_template, apple_rdf)) @prefix ex:    <http://example.org/instance/> . @prefix ncit:  <http://ncicb.nci.nih.gov/xml/owl/EVS/Thesaurus.owl#> . @prefix pato:  <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/PATO_> . @prefix iao:   <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/IAO_> . @prefix obi:   <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/OBI_> . @prefix ro:    <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/RO_> . @prefix uo:    <http://purl.obolibrary.org/obo/UO_> . @prefix rdf:   <http://www.w3.org/1999/02/22-rdf-syntax-ns#> . @prefix rdfs:  <http://www.w3.org/2000/01/rdf-schema#> . @prefix xsd:   <http://www.w3.org/2001/XMLSchema#> .  ############################################################ ## OBJECT: the particular apple ############################################################  ex:apple     rdf:type ncit:apple ;     rdfs:label "Apple X" ;     ro:has_quality ex:appleweight .  ############################################################ ## QUALITY: weight of the apple ############################################################  ex:appleweight     rdf:type pato:weight ;                 # PATO:weight     iao:is_about ex:apple ;     iao:is_quality_measured_as ex:appleweightDatum .  ############################################################ ## MEASUREMENT DATUM ############################################################  ex:appleweightDatum     rdf:type iao:0000109 ;                  # IAO:scalar measurement datum     obi:has_value_specification ex:appleweightValueSpec .  ############################################################ ## VALUE SPECIFICATION ############################################################  ex:appleweightValueSpec     rdf:type obi:0001938 ;                  # OBI:scalar value specification     iao:has_measurement_value "241.68"^^xsd:double ;     iao:has_measurement_unit_label uo:0000021 .  ############################################################ ## UNIT ############################################################  uo:0000021     rdf:type uo:grams .

title: Overview
text: single statement fairly trivial. real power Rosetta Statements comes lot statements using multiple templates. order make work, needs library templates. “library” simple data frame, specific headers. built command creates one (loads one properly formatted CSV) creates blank data frame. can add templates using add_template() function, pretty simple statement adds new template given string optional meta template ID (meta templates later). Let’s load set templates included example. can use read.csv() , init_library() function also verifies template file formatted properly: now data frame 3 templates apples. Let’s load statements: Now can convert statement data frame: loop mashes results one data frame. looks something like :
code: templates <- init_library() knitr::kable(templates) templates <- init_library(system.file("extdata/apple_templates.csv", package="rosettaR")) knitr::kable(templates) statements <- read.csv(system.file("extdata/apple_statements.csv", package="rosettaR")) knitr::kable(statements) results <- data.frame() merged <- dplyr::inner_join(statements, templates, by = "TemplateID") for (i in 1:nrow(merged)) {   row = merged[i, ] }

what: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything

text: goal rosettaR provide series tools work Rosetta Statements, plain language statements can converted semantic data paired template.

title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: can install development version rosettaR GitHub :

title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: basic example rosettaR can convert data:
code: library(rosettaR) statement <- "Kitchener is located in Canada" in_template <- "{{ city }} is located in {{ country }}" out_template <- "CITY,COUNTRY,,{{ city }},{{ country }}" df <- rosetta_format(statement, in_template, out_template)

title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: early version package. based idea Rosetta Statements described Rosetta Statements: Simplifying FAIR Knowledge Graph Construction User-Centered Approach Lars Vogt et al.

title: Turn Plain Language Statements Into RDF, CSV, or Anything
text: Implement slot restrictions validation using LinkML (major). Debug rework Shiny interface (major). Implement support optional slots. Add documentation working multiple template-statement pairs. Enhance Apple example use proper RDF, add data formats. Design hexagon logo rosettaR. Submit rosettaR CRAN. Submit rosettaR rOpenSci peer review.

title: Change a data frame into a series of statements based on templates. — df_to_statements
code: templates <- init_library() templates <- add_template(templates, apple_template) df <- data.frame(object = "Apple X",                               quality = "weight", value="100.2",                              unit="grams", TemplateID = "1") statements <- df_to_statements(df,templates)
